seo.title: Asylia.io – Bitcoin Fortress
seo.description: Asylia.io is a Bitcoin fortress built on multisignature, giving users full control over their keys while providing a reliable co-signer for critical situations. The Collaborative Partial Custody (CPC) model minimizes trust in third parties, fees are voluntary, and open-source code ensures auditability.

introMessage: “The Bitcoin Fortress, where sovereignty meets security. Protect your digital wealth with proven multisignature. Because true ownership means responsibility—today and for generations to come.”

wp.title: Quick overview (plainly)
wp.p1: What is multisignature and why do you need it?
wp.p2: Multisignature (multi-signature, or multisig) is a proven security mechanism that distributes control over bitcoins among multiple independent keys. A transaction only executes when at least M out of N keys authorize it (M-of-N scheme).
wp.point1: No single key holds too much power—neither an attacker nor a negligent user can spend funds alone.
wp.point2: Key loss ≠ bitcoin loss. As long as M keys remain accessible, you retain control.
wp.point3: Model flexibility. Involve hardware wallets, family, legal counsel, or Asylia’s vault.
wp.point4: Custom permissions. Define how many and which combination of keys is required—2-of-3, 3-of-5, 5-of-7…
wp.q2: Unlocking a Bitcoin wallet requires more keys than any single party holds independently.

p1.title: Private key / seed:
p1.p1: The secret code that generates and manages your wallet.
p1.p2: Never share it; store it offline (paper, safe, vault).

p2.title: Multisignature (multisig)
p2.p1: Sets an M-of-N rule. E.g., 2-of-3 signatures means any two out of three keys can spend.
p2.p2: Losing one key doesn’t cost you your bitcoins; one key alone can’t spend.

p3.title: Asylia as co-signer
p3.p1: By using the wallet backup type, the wallet config file becomes another key in the M-of-N scheme.
p3.p2: Funds remain under your control even if you lose Key 1 or Key 2, provided you have the config file. It acts as a software backup key for your hardware keys.

visual.title: Visual representation of multisig
visual.p: To illustrate, imagine our BTC wallet as a treasure chest. There are multiple ways to open it, and any single opening can empty the chest.
visual.b1: Traditional secure wallets as most know them.
visual.q2: More keys = less risk of loss or theft. Bitcoin stays in your hands; Asylia is just the safety net.

wp1.title: 1. Introduction: Why a Bitcoin Fortress?
wp1.p1: Phishing, malware, coercion, regulatory pressure, and human error threaten private key sovereignty. Historically, multisig has shown that distributing authority among independent parties removes a single point of failure and handles unexpected scenarios (key loss, kidnapping, extortion, death, inheritance). Asylia draws inspiration from medieval fortresses—strong walls, clear rules, and minimal blind trust.

wp2.title: 2. Why Asylia.io?
wp2.p1: Etymology: Asylia (Greek ἄσυλος) means 'territorial inviolability.' It symbolizes a place beyond unauthorized reach. The .io domain evokes input/output, emphasizing reliable, uninterrupted access to your bitcoins.

list1.title: We believe in:
list1.p1: Sovereignty & self-sovereignty—keys belong to the user.
list1.p3: Interoperability—honoring open Bitcoin standards (BIP-32/39/43/48, PSBT/BIP-174, Descriptors).
list1.p4: Open source & auditability—100% open-source under MIT.
list1.p5: Integrity—doing things right, even when no one is watching.

list3.title: Our promises
list3.p1: Independence—migrate freely to another platform; keys and bitcoins remain yours.
list3.p2: Security—no compromises; auditable code, proven hardware modules.
list3.p3: Transparency—open processes, public roadmaps, prompt issue disclosures.

list1.title: 4.1 Types of multisig wallets

p1.title: Backup:
p1.p2: Recovery if one user key is lost.

p2.title: Collaborative Signature:
p2.p1: 2-of-3 or 3-of-5, keys shared among multiple co-signers (family, lawyer, Asylia).

p3.title: Advanced multisig:
p3.p1: Any M-of-N as defined by descriptor.
p3.p2: For power users with custom threat models.

list1.p: Best practice: 2-of-3 for personal use or 3-of-5 for larger amounts. Asylia never holds quorum—funds cannot be spent without your consent.

list2.title: 4.2 Keys & hardware
list2.point_1: Supported HW wallets in MVP: Trezor, Ledger.
list2.point_2: Asylia’s internal keys: 2-of-3 multisig, each backed up via Shamir’s Secret Sharing and stored in offline HSM vaults.

list3.title: 4.3 Transaction flow
list3.point_2: Signature data transmitted via platform, QR codes, NFC, etc.
list3.point_3: Peer-to-peer signing. You control who receives signatures.

p1.title: No-KYC recovery:
p1.p2: Multisig partners according to M-of-N scheme.
p1.p3: BACKUP: Wallet config serves as one or more keys in the M-of-N scheme.

list5.title: 4.5 Architecture details
list5.p1: Serverless P2P communication using the decentralized NOSTR protocol.
list5.p2: Self-custody mode: no central backend; data stored only in encrypted browser localStorage.

wp5.title: 5. Who It’s For
wp5.point1: Long-term hodlers and responsible stewards of digital assets.
wp5.point3: Families, businesses, and trusts needing collective signing.
wp5.point4: Anyone who wants to safeguard wealth for future generations without compromise.

wp6.title: 6. Business Model & Fees
wp6.p1: Asylia.io operates with zero upfront or subscription fees. Users may optionally add support via a bitcoin output when sending a transaction.

legal.title: Legal Framework
legal.point1: MiCA: Asylia is a non-custodial software provider and not subject to CASP registration.
legal.point2: GDPR: IP logs and timestamps are pseudonymized and retained for 30 days.

wp7.title: 7. Risk Analysis (Threat Model)
wp7.point1: Key quorum compromise → multisig prevents unilateral fund escape.
wp7.point2: Insider risk at Asylia → open-source, HSMs, code reviews, asymmetric signing protocols.
wp7.point3: Supply-chain attack on HW wallet → hash checks, recommended official firmware.
wp7.point4: Social engineering & phishing → FIDO2/U2F auth, educational content, dual-channel confirmations.
wp7.point5: Infrastructure outage → offline PSBT, IPFS mirror, client migration options.

wp8.title: 8. Community & Collaboration
wp8.point2: BTC & multisig experts – BIP standard consultations.
wp8.point4: UX beta testers – iterative client improvements.
wp8.point5: Sponsors supporting a secure Bitcoin ecosystem.

wp9.title: 9. Disclaimer
wp9.p1: Asylia.io provides software 'as is.' Users bear full responsibility for private key management and legal compliance. Nothing here constitutes legal, tax, or investment advice.
wp9.p2: Legal context: Asylia is a non-custodial software provider and is not required to register as a CASP under MiCA.

wp10.title: 10. Conclusion: The Future Is Secure
wp10.p1: Medieval fortresses stood for centuries thanks to robust walls and honorable builders. Asylia brings that tradition to the digital age—security, sovereignty, and readiness for future generations.
wp10.q1:
“Fiat castrum securitatis, et portae fluctuum non praevalebunt.”
(Let the fortress of safety stand firm, and the gates of storms shall not prevail.)
wp10.q2: “Asylia is not here to grow fast. Asylia is here to endure.”

multisig_schema.title: Multisig scheme
multisig_schema.p: Backup, Co-sig, and multisig follow the same Bitcoin standard. The difference lies in their wallet use case.

backup.title: Backup
backup.p: A wallet type where the user holds the majority of keys and Asylia holds a minority. If the user loses one key, the platform backup key can restore access.

cosig.title: Co-sig
cosig.p: Collaborative signature where majority keys belong to owners and backup is distributed among multiple parties.

multisig.title: Multisig
multisig.p: A signing structure governed by a defined M-of-N scheme.
